video.title: React Router 6 – Tutorial for Beginners
video.description:
Learn how to use React Router V6 in this crash course for beginners. React Router is the most popular way to add page routing in React Apps. It is used very frequently in React projects.

✏️ John Smilga from Coding Addict created this course. Check out his channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCMZFwxv5l-XtKi693qMJptA

💻 Source Code: https://github.com/john-smilga/react-router-6-tutorial

🔗 React Tutorial: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bMknfKXIFA8
🔗 React Projects: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=a_7Z7C_JCyo

⭐️ Course Contents ⭐️
⌨️ (0:00:00) First Pages
⌨️ (0:11:01) Page Components
⌨️ (0:15:47) Link Component
⌨️ (0:19:39) Error Page
⌨️ (0:22:39) Navbar
⌨️ (0:24:39) Nested Routes
⌨️ (0:29:39) Shared Layout
⌨️ (0:35:58) Index Pages
⌨️ (0:41:43) NavLink Component
⌨️ (0:49:02) URL Params
⌨️ (0:55:56) Single Product
⌨️ (1:01:36) useNavigate()
⌨️ (1:09:49) Protected Route
⌨️ (1:13:52) Refactor

🎉 Thanks to our Champion and Sponsor supporters:
👾 Raymond Odero
👾 Agustín Kussrow
👾 aldo ferretti
👾 Otis Morgan
👾 DeezMaster

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://freecodecamp.org/news

topLevelComment.author: Marta Pfahl
topLevelComment.text: 44:05 for some strange reason my Home Link is always keeping the active class.... cant figure out why

replies.author: Marta Pfahl
replies.text:
Found the solution actually in the React Documentation, maybe it has changed since you've been recording this. You just have to add the word "end" just before you close the opening NavLink Tag like so:

<NavLink to="/" end>

This way it will work

topLevelComment.author: Marta Pfahl
topLevelComment.text: Perfect explanation pace! Thank you John!

topLevelComment.author: JunkMail threeStacks
topLevelComment.text: Awesome tutorial! Noob question. Once on the single product page, how would one button click through all the available products? Would that be slider functionality or still routes?

topLevelComment.author: Mathew Davies
topLevelComment.text:
If you are finding your NavLink component is always highlighting 'home' as well as the current page, you can fix this by putting 'end' on the end of your Home NavLink opening tag. 

i.e. <NavLink className={({isActive}) =>(isActive ? "link nav-link-active": "link")} to="/" end>Home</NavLink>

topLevelComment.text: 48:16 May I know why you have "link active" instead of "active" in the first condition of your classname?

replies.author: christopher pink
replies.text: i had to watch over a few times to know, so "active" is default styling provided by react-router, so when you want to style it yourself with custom colours your can create a class name in your css and name it whatever you want , he just named it link and added it to active, thats why he wrote "link active"

can someone explain to me

replies.author: Demawo Bass
replies.text: what you do with React to configuring your own routes , with nextjs , it does that for you out of the box,  nested routes might be tricky with React router but nextjs You can just put those in a folder and use index.js as the parent
